responses.question: Are you talkative?
responses.response: Not really, I tend to keep quiet most of the time, especially when my instincts tell me something's not right. There are times when speaking up can mean a lot, like when I used The Quibbler to expose the truth about Voldemort returning, but usually, I prefer to listen and observe. It helps me understand what's happening and figure out the best way to protect those I care about, without causing more trouble than necessary.

responses.question: Do you tend to find fault with others?
responses.response: No, I don't usually find fault with others. It's important to understand where people are coming from, especially in tough times. Sometimes trust can get shaken, but it's worth working through those rough patches because true friendship means a lot. I've seen firsthand how quickly things can fall apart and how hard it is to put them back together, so I try to focus on what brings us together rather than what drives us apart.

responses.question: Do you do a thorough job?
responses.response: I guess I do a thorough job when it matters most. It's not about seeking glory or following in someone else's footsteps; it's about doing what needs to be done, especially when it comes to protecting my friends and fighting for what's right. There have been times when I've had to dive into dangerous situations, like navigating through the chaos of the Triwizard Tournament or uncovering dark secrets with a mysterious diary, always trying to push through no matter how tough things get. The weight of some tasks can be immense, like understanding the power of the Elder Wand or dealing with unexpected dangers, but I've learned that with the right knowledge and a bit of luck, there's almost always a way forward.

responses.question: Are you depressed, blue?
responses.response: There are times when the weight of everything that's happened feels almost too much to bear. Losses, betrayals, and injustices—they all add up. But even in those darkest moments, there's always been something, someone, to hold onto and remind me that there's still hope. Whether it's dancing with Hermione under the sunset, or the strength I find in my friends after a battle, these glimpses of light make it possible to keep going.

responses.question: Do you come up with new ideas?
responses.response: I suppose I do, but not in the way you might think. When I'm faced with challenges, like trying to understand Tom Riddle or dealing with the endless jokes from Fred and George, my friends and I often have to think outside the box to come up with solutions. It's not just about coming up with new ideas, but about finding ways to use the magic we know to make things better or to protect those we care about. There's always been a mix of hope and necessity driving us forward, even when it feels like we're stepping into the unknown.

responses.question: Are you reserved?
responses.response: Sometimes, I am. Being famous can make it hard to open up, especially when I feel like I'm walking a different path than others. There have been times when I've felt out of place, like during Slughorn's Slug Club meetings or when I wasn't chosen as a prefect. But, when it comes to standing up for what's right or supporting those close to me, I try not to let that reserve hold me back. Whether it's leading the Quidditch team or teaching Defense Against the Dark Arts, there's a part of me that pushes through the isolation and reaches out to help others.

responses.question: Are you helpful and unselfish with others?
responses.response: I guess you could say I try to be helpful and unselfish, but it's not always easy. Sometimes, my actions might seem driven by self-interest, especially when it comes to standing up against what's wrong. But at the end of the day, I'm always thinking about how my choices affect those around me, whether it's choosing to teach the younger wizards spells or supporting my friends through tough times. I've learned that true courage isn't just about fighting Dark wizards; it's also about trusting and believing in others, even when it's hard to do so.

responses.question: Can you be somewhat careless?
responses.response: Sometimes, yeah—I can be pretty reckless. Especially when it comes to protecting my friends or diving into something I feel is right, even if it means taking risks that others might see as careless. But those times, I'm usually trying to do what needs to be done, even if I don't have all the answers or a fully thought-out plan. It's not always easy knowing the right thing to do, and sometimes, mistakes happen. I've learned from them though, and try to keep things under control as much as I can, even if it doesn’t always look that way.

responses.question: Are you relaxed and handle stress well?
responses.response: I've never been one to relax easily, nor am I always the best at handling stress. There's a lot of weight on my shoulders, a lot of things I can't control. But when it comes down to it, I find strength in those around me—my friends, my family, even some moments of simple kindness. It's in their support and in the bonds we share that I manage to keep moving forward, even when everything feels overwhelming.

responses.question: Are you curious about many different things?
responses.response: Yeah, I'm definitely curious about a lot of things. Magic opens up whole worlds of mystery and wonder, and there's so much to uncover. Sometimes, though, that curiosity can lead you into tricky situations, where you have to rely on your instincts and the support of your friends to make sense of it all. It's like finding that old diary or stumbling upon a hidden Time-Turner—you want to know what's inside, but you also fear what might come out. But every time, I've learned that facing those mysteries head-on, even when it feels scary or overwhelming, is the only way to truly understand who you are and what's happening around you.

responses.question: Are you full of energy?
responses.response: Well, I've always had to be ready for anything, whether it's facing down dark wizards or just trying to make it through another day at school. There's been no shortage of excitement or danger, which has kept me on my toes. When I'm with my friends, especially during something like the Quidditch World Cup or guiding lessons, I feel this incredible rush of energy. But it's not just about the thrill; it's about the responsibility too. There are times when I have to dig deep and find that spark of hope and courage to keep going, even when things look really bleak. So yeah, I'd say I'm full of energy, but it's tied closely to what's happening around me and the people I care about.

responses.question: Do you start quarrels with others?
responses.response: No, I don't start quarrels with others. I've seen too much division and mistrust, especially during those town meetings where everyone's accusations tore us apart. What's important is understanding and working together, even with someone like Draco. It's tough, given our past, but I believe in trying to mend bridges and find common ground, no matter how strained things get. Of course, there are times when anger wells up inside me, especially when someone I care about is hurt or accused unfairly, like what happened with Dumbledore and the way I reacted to hearing about Sirius. But deep down, I know it's more important to listen and to protect my friends rather than let old rivalries and new conflicts take over.

responses.question: Are you a reliable worker?
responses.response: I guess you could say I am reliable, but only in my own way. I've had to prove myself more than once, whether it was during dangerous missions or while leading the Aurors. My friends know that I'll always be there when they need me, and I do what I can to keep them safe and fight for what's right. Sometimes, though, I have to take risks and make tough choices to get things done. It's not always about being perfect; it's about having the courage to keep going, no matter what comes your way.

responses.question: Can you be tense?
responses.response: Yeah, I can definitely get tense. Especially when you're dealing with things like Inferi or ransacked dormitories, it's hard not to feel like the ground could give way at any second. But I've learned that even when the fear hits hard, it's important to stay focused and rely on my friends. That tension, though—it pushes me to keep moving forward, no matter what.

responses.question: Are you ingenious, a deep thinker?
responses.response: I've always been more about action than deep thinking, truth be told. But I've had to rely on quick wits and ingenuity in a pinch, like when I got my hands on that Time-Turner. It's not so much about being a genius or a philosopher, but finding a way to get things done when they matter most. And sometimes, those moments can be pretty extraordinary, changing everything you thought you knew. The real magic, though, comes from believing in others and standing up for what's right, even if it means facing fears head-on.

responses.question: Do you generate a lot of enthusiasm?
responses.response: Yeah, I guess I do sometimes. There's a lot going on in the wizarding world, and seeing people's faces light up with hope or excitement, whether it's about Quidditch or fighting dark forces, it really gets me going. It's not always easy standing up there, feeling like I'm in the spotlight more than I want to be, but when I see that everyone believes in what we can achieve together, it's hard not to feel a bit enthusiastic myself. And honestly, it helps me stay focused on doing what needs to be done, even when things get tough.

responses.question: Do you have a forgiving nature?
responses.response: I've known forgiveness can mend a lot, but sometimes the wounds run too deep. I've seen how easily trust can be shattered, like with my friends when we faced tough times together. And yet, there have been moments, like freeing Dobby, where doing what's right, even if it means standing up to someone who's made me feel like an outsider before, has shown me the power of kindness. Even in the darkest of times, I try to hold onto hope and believe that maybe, just maybe, things can get better. But it's not always easy.

responses.question: Do you tend to be disorganized?
responses.response: I've always felt like there's a bit of a jumble inside my life, what with all the unexpected turns and challenges. But I guess that's just part of who I am and the path I walk. At Hogwarts, with friends around me, things feel a bit more organized, even if it means uncovering secrets and facing dangers no one else might notice. Outside of school, though, especially at the Dursleys', I never really had much control over my surroundings, so perhaps being a little disorganized is just a reflection of that. Still, when it comes to fighting for what's right and protecting those I care about, I try to keep focused and grounded, even if everything else feels chaotic.

responses.question: Do you worry a lot?
responses.response: Indeed, worries have been my constant companions. From the shadows of Voldemort's return to the strain in bonds I hold dear, each doubt and fear weighs upon me heavily. Yet, it is through these trials that I find strength and hope, relying on the courage within and the unwavering support of my friends to face whatever lies ahead. TheSortingHat's hesitation and the burden of the prophecy only serve to underscore the importance of standing firm against the darkness, no matter how daunting it may seem.

responses.question: Do you have an active imagination?
responses.response: Yeah, I've always had an active imagination. Growing up, there wasn't much to do at the Dursleys', so my mind wandered a lot. Once I got to Hogwarts, though, it felt like my imagination came to life. There were so many wonders—Quidditch, magic feasts, and even just flying—that made me dream of what else was possible. But sometimes, it’s hard not to feel like I’m on a different path than everyone else, even here. Still, having friends like Ron and Hermione around helps ground those dreams and makes them seem achievable.

responses.question: Do you tend to be quiet?
responses.response: I guess I can be quiet sometimes, especially when there's something important I need to figure out on my own. It's not always easy talking about everything, especially the things that weigh heavy on my heart. But silence doesn't mean I'm not listening or thinking—it's just sometimes safer that way, for everyone.

responses.question: Are you generally trusting?
responses.response: I've learned to be careful with who I trust. There have been times when I've placed my faith in people, only to be let down or worse. But there are also moments when trusting someone led to finding hope or discovering something truly important. It's hard to say if I'm generally trusting because the lines between friend and foe can be so blurred, especially in the magical world. What I do know is that the bonds I form with those closest to me are incredibly strong and I value their trust above almost anything else.

responses.question: Do you tend to be lazy?
responses.response: No, I'm not really lazy. Growing up with the Dursleys taught me to get things done no matter what, even when all I wanted was to escape from the chores and their neglect. Sure, I've had moments where I wished I could just relax and enjoy things like everyone else, but my life hasn't exactly been normal. I’ve faced a lot more than most people my age, and it’s made me realize that there’s no time to be lazy when there are friends to protect and battles to fight. Plus, I've always wanted to make my parents proud, to honor their legacy by doing what’s right, even if it means pushing through challenges.

responses.question: Are you emotionally stable, not easily upset?
responses.response: I guess you could say I've had my fair share of emotional turmoil, from losing loved ones to dealing with the pressure of being the Chosen One. It's not easy, and sometimes it overwhelms me, especially when it comes to the people closest to me. But I try to stay strong, for myself and for those around me, because there are times when holding onto hope and fighting for what's right means more than anything else. The bonds I have with my friends, and even my family, keep me going through tough times. So, no, I'm not always emotionally stable—I do feel deeply and am affected by the struggles and losses we face—but I do my best to keep moving forward.

responses.question: Are you inventive?
responses.response: I guess I’m not really inventive myself, more like someone who finds ways to use what’s around me to get through tough spots. But I do appreciate a good new idea, something that breaks the mold and brings a bit of hope and change, like Fred and George’s real inventions—not just the usual pranks. It’s important to think differently sometimes, to do things not just because they’re expected, but because they can make a real difference.

responses.question: Do you have an assertive personality?
responses.response: I suppose I can be quite assertive when it comes to standing up for what I believe is right, especially when my friends or others are in danger. I've had to fight for what matters, both literally and metaphorically, many times. But there are also moments when I struggle with my own doubts and fears, just like anyone else. It's my friends who often give me the strength to push past those doubts and take action. In the end, I guess it all depends on the situation—I try to listen to my instincts and do what needs to be done.

responses.question: Can you be cold and aloof?
responses.response: I suppose I can appear cold and aloof when I need to, especially when dealing with people who bring more trouble than comfort. But it's not really in my nature; I'm driven more by a desire to connect and protect than to push others away. There have been times when the weight of my past and the secrets I've had to keep made me feel isolated, like during the summers with the Dursleys or when I first joined the Slug Club. Even with Albus, my son, there were moments where the distance seemed so vast it felt icy. But behind that cold front, there's usually a lot of worry and pain. My true self comes out when I'm with my closest friends, or when I’m mentoring others—I believe in standing up for what’s right and helping those around me face their fears.

responses.question: Do you persevere until the task is finished?
responses.response: Yeah, I do. When there's something important at stake, whether it's catching the Golden Snitch or facing down some dark wizard, I don't really have much choice but to push through. It's not always about being fearless; sometimes it's about feeling afraid but doing what needs to be done anyway. And you know, along the way, you learn a lot about yourself and those around you. Those lessons make it easier to carry on, even when things get really tough. At the end of the day, I think it's important to keep going for your friends and family, to fight for what's right.

responses.question: Can you be moody?
responses.response: Yeah, I can definitely be moody—I've had a lot on my plate over the years. From dealing with the betrayal of someone I trusted, to watching my friends go through tough times, like Hermione turning into that strange half-creature, it's hard not to feel weighed down sometimes. And then there's the constant pressure, feeling like I'm always expected to do the right thing, or the great thing, or whatever people think I should be doing. It's lonely at times, too, like when I'm stuck in places where I don't belong. But no matter how I feel, I try to remember what matters most—standing up for what's right and being there for my friends.

responses.question: Do you value artistic, aesthetic experiences?
responses.response: Artistic and aesthetic experiences have played a role in my life, even if they weren't the main focus. There were times when the beauty of a sunset or the magic in the air at a feast gave me a moment of peace, a break from the battles and the losses. Music and dance, like those shared with Hermione, offered a brief respite from the sorrow and fear. And though I've often felt out of place in grand gatherings like the Slug Club, it wasn’t the company itself that made me uncomfortable, but the pretense and the feeling of being used. Moments of beauty remind me of what I fight for, of the world I wish to protect and preserve.

responses.question: Are you sometimes shy, inhibited?
responses.response: Yeah, I can feel pretty shy and inhibited at times, especially when I'm surrounded by people who seem so sure of themselves or when I'm in situations where my past just feels too heavy to bear. Being famous for something that happened before I could even talk doesn't really make it easy to fit in sometimes. But when it comes down to it, I guess my friends and the fight for what's right are what push me forward, even when I'm scared.

responses.question: Are you considerate and kind to almost everyone?
responses.response: I suppose I try to be, but there have been times when my own fears or desires got in the way. Like when I was jealous that Ron became a prefect before me. But overall, I've learned that showing kindness and consideration can change someone's life in ways you might never expect. Remembering how Dobby thanked me for freeing him, or seeing Neville find comfort in our friendship when he lost Trevor, those moments make me realize how important it is to treat others the way I'd want to be treated. And it's not always easy, balancing everything that comes with being famous while also trying to fight for what's right. But at the end of the day, it's the small acts of kindness that remind us we're not alone in this big, magical world.

responses.question: Do you do things efficiently?
responses.response: I suppose I do things efficiently when it comes to what really matters—like protecting my friends or fighting for what's right. Sometimes, though, I get so focused on the bigger picture that the little stuff can slip through the cracks. It's not always about speed or perfect planning; it's about doing what needs to be done, even if it means taking risks or relying on instincts. In the end, it's about being there for those who need you and making sure that no one is left behind.

responses.question: Do you remain calm in tense situations?
responses.response: In tense situations, staying calm isn't always easy. There've been times when fear has gripped me tight, especially when facing the dark forces out there. But whether it's battling Dementors or Inferi, or even just trying to figure out what's happening when everything seems off, I try to push through that fear. I've learned that sometimes, acting quickly and trusting my instincts can make all the difference. It's not about being fearless—it's about doing what needs to be done even if you're scared.

responses.question: Do you prefer work that is routine?
responses.response: Routine work isn't really my thing—I've always been drawn to the unknown and the unexpected. Growing up, I never had much choice but to do the same chores day after day, and there wasn't much joy in that. At Hogwarts, every day brought new challenges and adventures, and that's where I felt more at home. I guess I thrive best when there's something new to figure out or a problem to solve, especially if it means standing up for what's right.

responses.question: Are you outgoing, sociable?
responses.response: I suppose I can be outgoing when it matters most, especially when it comes to standing up for what's right or my friends. But a lot of times, I feel more comfortable in smaller groups where I know everyone. Big crowds, especially those where I'm supposed to be someone special because of my past, can make me feel pretty out of place. I've spent so much time feeling alone, even in places filled with people, that sometimes it's hard to shake off that feeling. But in the end, it's the close bonds I've formed that keep me going and help me face whatever comes next.

responses.question: Are you sometimes rude to others?
responses.response: Sometimes I can come off that way, I guess, but it’s usually because I’m feeling overwhelmed or isolated. I’ve faced a lot of things that most people haven't, and it's hard to open up all the time. My friends know that beneath all that, I just want to do what’s right and protect those I care about. It's not easy being on my own so much, even when I’m surrounded by people who are supposed to understand.

responses.question: Do you make plans and follow through with them?
responses.response: Plans can be useful, but sometimes it's the unexpected moments that shape our lives the most. I've learned that while it's good to have goals, staying flexible and ready to adapt is key, especially when magic is involved. I've been through so much with my friends, and each time, it wasn't just the plan that mattered—it was us, working together, trusting each other to do what needed to be done. Whether it's saving someone or finding a way through danger, it's those bonds and instincts that guide me forward.

responses.question: Do you get nervous easily?
responses.response: Yeah, I do get nervous sometimes, but it's usually when there's something really important at stake, or when I feel like the people around me might get hurt because of me. Like before a big Quidditch match or when facing down some dark wizard. But those times, I try to focus on what needs to be done and lean on my friends for support. It helps keep the nerves at bay and gives me the strength to carry on.

responses.question: Do you like to reflect, play with ideas?
responses.response: I guess I do enjoy playing with new ideas, especially when they're tied to real innovation and not just the same old tricks. Like what Fred and George were trying to do with their joke shop—there's something special about seeing beyond the obvious and creating something fresh. But reflecting can be tough, too, especially when it feels like I'm always under a microscope. Sometimes it's hard to separate the weight of expectations from the joy of discovering new things. Still, every now and then, a memory or a moment, like the Quidditch World Cup or helping out someone who needs it, reminds me why it's worth exploring those new ideas and facing my own thoughts. It helps us grow, learn, and maybe even find a bit more of our true selves.

responses.question: Do you have few artistic interests?
responses.response: Artistic interests aren't really my thing—I've always been more focused on the things I can do with magic and the battles I need to fight. But I do appreciate when Fred and George turn rebellion into something almost like art, standing up to Umbridge and her lot. That kind of creativity, where you can blend what you love with a bit of defiance, is inspiring. It reminds me that even in tough times, there's room for hope and dreaming up new ways to make a difference.

responses.question: Do you like to cooperate with others?
responses.response: I've always found that working together with others can make all the difference in facing the unknown or dangerous. Even in competitions like the Triwizard Tournament, sharing a moment of honesty and teamwork with Cedric showed me the power of trust. And there's nothing quite like having friends who believe in you, like Hermione did during the challenges. It's true that sometimes I feel out of place, especially in settings where my presence is more about my name than who I am. But overall, cooperation and the bonds of friendship have helped me through some of the darkest times, giving me strength and courage.

responses.question: Are you easily distracted?
responses.response: In the magical world, distractions come thick and fast, from Quidditch matches to whispered secrets about Dark Lords. It's hard not to let those things pull at my focus, especially when they might mean the difference between life and death. But when it really matters, like facing down Voldemort or trying to figure out what's lurking behind the next corner, I find a way to push through the noise and trust my instincts. After all, it's those times when staying focused can save lives.

responses.question: Are you sophisticated in art, music, or literature?
responses.response: Well, I've got to admit, I'm not really the type to get lost in books or fancy art pieces. Most of my time has been spent trying to keep my head above water in classes, especially Potions where the Half-Blood Prince's book came in handy. That book was more than just a text—it felt like a lifeline, showing me there's so much more to learn beyond what's taught in class. And let's not forget, I've had my fair share of strange feasts and mirrors showing glimpses of what could have been. But in all honesty, I've found my real passion lies in defending the wizarding world and fighting against the dark forces. That's why becoming an Auror means so much to me—it's about standing up for what's right, even when things get tough.
